body:
This code does look suspicious for cases when CRLF are split across buffer boundaries:

https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/4.1/codec-http/src/main/java/io/netty/handler/codec/http/multipart/HttpPostBodyUtil.java#L164-L168

IMHO, it is the contrary:
- when the CR is there but not LF, then it returns -1 since it does not found the boundary ending
- when it gets the next buffer, then LF will be found
However, I think I can do a reproducer as you described (very easy). It will then show the bug, if any, and finally I will propose a fix (of course, if I found the root cause).

Just to let you know that I can reproduce with the following scenario (could you confirm that this one is the same as yours):
- Last-1 buffer contains last chunk + CR only (no LF)
- Last buffer contains LF and separator (with LF/CRLF at the end, but even with a n+1 buffer containing LF or CRLF it's the same)
- Issue is on Last-1 buffer: CR is included in the final data (which should not)

If the following scenario occurs, it's OK:
- Last-1 buffer contains last chunk + LF/CRLF + separator + CR
- Last buffer contains LF
- No issue

Another one OK:
- Last-1 buffer contains last chunk + LF/CRLF
- Last buffer contains separator + CRLF/LF
- No issue

> Last-1 buffer contains last chunk + CR only (no LF)
> Issue is on Last-1 buffer: CR is included in the final data (which should not)

yep, this sounds like the issue we're having.

> Last buffer contains LF and separator

I haven't confirmed this detail yet (because well, things crash when processing Last-1 buffer), but I can try to do that if that would help.
The last buffer did indeed contain `\n--9dd083c5bacd1377--\r\n`
OK, thanks ! I'm trying to find out the best way to fix it (with no new issue of course)...

issue.title: [FLINK-24197] Guard against CLRF being split across chunks
issue.body:
This PR adds a defense mechanism against https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/11668.
If the CRLF prefix of a multipart delimiter is split across 2 chunks an exception is thrown because Netty incorrectly treats CR as data.
If CR is the last byte of the current chunk, then we pessimistically assume that this case occurred.
We exclude the trailing CR from the current chunk, and add it to the front of the next received chunk.

issue.title: Fix CRLF split between 2 buffers before separator

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:

When a buffer ends with the last chunk for a part but containing
only a CR and no LF neither separator, it ends up with the CR
included within the content of the part, which is wrong.

Modification:

Rare case, but fixed by checking when not getting the delimiter,
not finding a LineBreak, we check if the last byte of the chunk is a CR
and if the content could be added to the current part (current length +
current buffer length - 1) could lead to the end of the part.

Result:

If the CR is not part of the HttpData, then the CR can be safely ignored, 
waiting for the future LF and separator, and the buffer minus this CR 
can be added to the part content.

If not, the CR is part of the content and shall be included in the HttpData.

Add a non regression test.


Fixes #11668

issue.title: Issue with CRLF in multipart upload in Netty

repository.name: jooby
repository.description: The modular web framework for Java and Kotlin

issue.body:
Netty v4.1.68.Final has an issue related to CRLF in some multipart uploads that we encounter when using Jooby with Netty: https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/11668

A fix har already been proposed and will probably be available soon.
